newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan insurers may tread carefully in new market.
newsitem.headline: Japan insurers may tread carefully in new market.

text.p: Japan's insurance giants are expected to voluntarily restrain themselves even though they will be allowed to invade each other's turf once the market is deregulated in October.
Industry sources and analysts say it will take at least five years or more for insurers-- now divided into specialist life or non-life insurance companies -- to turn a profit in their new business.
This is partly because the insurers will voluntarily limit the range of business they engage in in order not to jeopardise smaller insurers and foreign insurers in Japan, they said.
Washington has protested Tokyo's newly revised insurance law which it says violates a U.S.-Japan trade agreement, and the dispute overshadows the process of deregulation, they said.
An amendment to a Japanese law on the insurance market took effect in April, allowing insurers to conduct both life and non-life insurance business through subsidiaries.
Earlier this month, 11 Japanese non-life insurance companies and six life insurance firms set up subsidiaries to enter each other's business.
Previously, insurance companies could operate only in one business sector.
"The changes are expected to benefit consumers by making it easier to take out a variety of insurance policies with one insurer," said one insurance company official.
However, insurers have decided on a "go-slow" approach to avoid any radical change in the business environment, he said.
"The gap between big and small insurers is wide and we don't want to see the collapse of small insurers soon after deregulation," he said.

Josei Itoh, president of Japan's biggest life insurance company Nippon Life Insurance Co, recently told Reuters that it would take about 10 years for both non-life and life insurance subsidiaries to get under way.
"We are worried about the entry (of non-life insurers) in our fields, and it might become a cause of turbulence in the short term," he said.

On Monday, major Japanese non-life insurance company Yasuda Fire & Marine Co Ltd announced it would take a majority stake in the Japanese unit of U.S. life insurance giant CIGNA Corp, the first time a Japanese non-life insurance company has purchased a life insurance subsidiary.
Industry sources said that Yasuda had avoided establishing a subsidiary as it believed that restrictions would make it less profitable to set up a life insurance arm.
Analysts said that Yasuda Fire made a good move.

Takehito Yamanaka, an analyst at New Japan Securities Research Institute, said Yasuda's purchase of a big stake in INA Life Insurance would probably give it a ready client base and allow it to offer a full range of products.

"While Japan decided to deregulate the insurance industry, the U.S.-Japan insurance talks have not been agreed yet, and some restrictions on subsidiaries' business will remain for some years," Yamanaka said.
"Yasuda would probably enjoy a wide range of life insurance business through INA than the life insurance arms of non-life insurers," he said.

Yasuda president Koichi Ariyoshi said on Monday that he expects Yasuda, through INA, will be able to offer a full range of insurance products, including those in the hotly contested "third-sector" niche market.

Japan and the United States agreed in 1994 that the implementation of the new insurance business law will not lead to any radical change in the third-sector market, which covers such items as personal accident, sickness and nursing care, the stronghold of foreign insurers.
However, Washington is unhappy with the process of deregulation in the third-sector market under the revised insurance law.
Several rounds of talks have been held since January to resolve the situation, and new talks are scheduled for some time in September.
